markdownRemark.html:
Describing Adam Optimization

  • Adam stands for adaptive moment estimation
  • Adam is almost always more performant than the standard gradient descent algorithm
  • Adam is an optimization algorithm that essentially combines momentum and rmsprop

  • Adam is an extension of mini-batch gradient descent

    • Mini-batch gradient descent is a configuration of stochastic gradient descent
    • Therefore, we'll sometimes see that Adam is an extension of stochastic gradient descent
  • Adam uses the hyperparameters βv\beta_{v}βv​, βs\beta_{s}βs​, α\alphaα, and ϵ\epsilonϵ
  • Adam is generally regarded as being fairly robust to the choice of hyper parameters, though the learning rate sometimes needs to be changed from the suggested default

Defining Adam Optimization

  1. Compute dWdWdW and dbdbdb on the current mini-batch ttt

    • Where dW=∂J(w,b)∂wdW = \frac{\partial J(w,b)}{\partial w}dW=∂w∂J(w,b)​
    • Where db=∂J(w,b)∂bdb = \frac{\partial J(w,b)}{\partial b}db=∂b∂J(w,b)​
  2. Update each www parameter as the following:
vt=βvvt−1+(1−βv)dW}=momentumst=βsst−1+(1−βs)dW2}=rmspropvtcorrected=vt1−βvt}=bias correctionstcorrected=st1−βst}=bias correction\begin{aligned} v_{t} = \beta_{v} v_{t-1} + (1-\beta_{v})dW \qquad \rbrace &= \text{momentum} \cr s_{t} = \beta_{s} s_{t-1} + (1-\beta_{s})dW^{2} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{rmsprop} \cr v_{t}^{corrected} = \frac{v_{t}}{1-\beta_{v}^{t}} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{bias correction} \cr s_{t}^{corrected} = \frac{s_{t}}{1-\beta_{s}^{t}} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{bias correction} \end{aligned}vt​=βv​vt−1​+(1−βv​)dW}st​=βs​st−1​+(1−βs​)dW2}vtcorrected​=1−βvt​vt​​}stcorrected​=1−βst​st​​}​=momentum=rmsprop=bias correction=bias correction​ Wt=Wt−1−αvtcorrectedstcorrected+ϵW_{t} = W_{t-1} - \alpha \frac{v_{t}^{corrected}}{\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}} + \epsilon}Wt​=Wt−1​−αstcorrected​​+ϵvtcorrected​​
  1. Update each bbb parameter as the following:
vt=βvvt−1+(1−βv)db}=momentumst=βsst−1+(1−βs)db2}=rmspropvtcorrected=vt1−βvt}=bias correctionstcorrected=st1−βst}=bias correction\begin{aligned} v_{t} = \beta_{v} v_{t-1} + (1-\beta_{v})db \qquad \rbrace &= \text{momentum} \cr s_{t} = \beta_{s} s_{t-1} + (1-\beta_{s})db^{2} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{rmsprop} \cr v_{t}^{corrected} = \frac{v_{t}}{1-\beta_{v}^{t}} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{bias correction} \cr s_{t}^{corrected} = \frac{s_{t}}{1-\beta_{s}^{t}} \qquad \rbrace &= \text{bias correction} \end{aligned}vt​=βv​vt−1​+(1−βv​)db}st​=βs​st−1​+(1−βs​)db2}vtcorrected​=1−βvt​vt​​}stcorrected​=1−βst​st​​}​=momentum=rmsprop=bias correction=bias correction​ Wt=Wt−1−αvtcorrectedstcorrected+ϵW_{t} = W_{t-1} - \alpha \frac{v_{t}^{corrected}}{\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}} + \epsilon}Wt​=Wt−1​−αstcorrected​​+ϵvtcorrected​​

  1. Repeat the above steps for each ttht^{th}tth iteration of mini-batch

    • Note that our hyperparameters are βv\beta_{v}βv​, βs\beta_{s}βs​, α\alphaα, and ϵ\epsilonϵ here

Adam Hyperparameters

  • The hyperparameter βv\beta_{v}βv​ refers to computing the mean of dWdWdW
  • The hyperparameter βs\beta_{s}βs​ refers to computing the mean of dW2dW^{2}dW2
  • The hyperparameter α\alphaα typically needs to be tuned
  • The hyperparameter ϵ\epsilonϵ is never tuned

  • The hyperparameter βv\beta_{v}βv​ typically doesn't need to be tuned

    • The default value is typically left unchanged
    • The default value of βv\beta_{v}βv​ is 0.90.90.9

  • The hyperparameter βs\beta_{s}βs​ typically doesn't need to be tuned

    • The default value is typically left unchanged
    • The default value of βs\beta_{s}βs​ is 0.9990.9990.999

Interpreting Adam Optimization

  • Note, the dW2dW^{2}dW2 is an element-wise operation, since WWW represents a vector of weights

  • Also note, ϵ\epsilonϵ represents some small number that ensures numerical stability

    • The default value of this is typically ϵ=10−8\epsilon = 10^{-8}ϵ=10−8
    • This value is essentially negligable for interpretation purposes
  • Essentially, we're taking the benefit of smoothness by applying exponential weights to our gradient descent function
  • Therefore, the steps should become smoother as we increase β\betaβ
  • This is because we're averaging out the previous steps iterations
  • As a result, we shouldn't be bouncing up and down around the same parameter value as much, since the average of these partial derivatives are essentially 000
  • And, we should be quickly moving sideways towards the optimal parameter value, since the average of these partial derivatives are much larger than 000
  • We're also gaining a smoothness benefit from vtcorrectedstcorrected\frac{v_{t}^{corrected}}{\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}}}stcorrected​​vtcorrected​​
  • This is essentially a ratio of the bias-corrected momentum term to the bias-corrected rmsprop terms

  • Therefore, we will get a dampening-out effect if:

    • The stcorrected\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}}stcorrected​​ term is very large
    • The vtcorrectedv_{t}^{corrected}vtcorrected​ term is very small

  • On the other hand, we will quickly gravitate toward the optimal parameter values if either of the following are true:

    • The stcorrected\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}}stcorrected​​ term is very small

      • The vtcorrectedv_{t}^{corrected}vtcorrected​ term is very large

tldr

  • Adam optimization can be thought of as standard gradient descent that has been given a short-term memory
  • Adam optimization attempts to average out the oscillations around the same value (in a given direction) by apply exponentially weighted averages to standard gradient descent
  • It also gains a smoothness benefit from updating parameters using the vtcorrectedstcorrected\frac{v_{t}^{corrected}}{\sqrt{s_{t}^{corrected}}}stcorrected​​vtcorrected​​ terms
  • Adam optimization is almost always faster than the standard gradient descent algorithm
